dict.string: Concatenation (5!)
!ConcatSprint

Dear ____,  


Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. I am very sorry to hear that your Sprint end user received the SMS messages in segments. 


Please note that this is a limitation on Sprint's platform where Sprint does not support concatenated messages over long codes only. Messages sent to Sprint over short codes will support concatenation. Unfortunately, this is out of Twilio's control. Twilio fully supports concatenation for both long codes and short codes, however, if the destination carriers do not support concatenation, messages will not be concatenated. 


%fillpopup:name=Sprint Behavior Option1:default=Some of the developers that we work with will number their messages with [1] or [2] to delineate an order. :option 2:option 3:option 4:option 5:%


%fillpopup:name=Sprint Behavior Option 2:default=Messages will be broken down in segments with page references (1/3, 2/3, 3/3). Also, please note that the page reference characters will be added in the **total character of the message**. Messages will be either segmented as a 160 character chunks or a 70 character chunks when unicode characters are being used in the message. Please see below for more information- https-//support.twilio.com/hc/en-us/articles/223134307-Why-are-my-messages-with-unicode-being-split- https-//support.twilio.com/hc/en-us/articles/223181508-Does-Twilio-support-concatenated-SMS-messages-or-messages-over-160-characters-:option 2:option 3:option 4:option 5%


%fillpopup:name=Sprint Behavior Option 3 - Recommend Lookups API:default=Another tool that you may find useful is our Lookups API that can indicate carrier information. You can implement this API into your existing application logic to query carrier information, so that you will know that messages can potentially be sent out of order and you may need to put numbering in the messages. https://www.twilio.com/docs/api/lookups:option 2:option 3:option 4:option 5%


Please let me know if there is anything else I can help you with or further clarify. More than happy to help. 


Warmest Regards,
Concat - Sprint Does not Support 1600 Characters over Long Codes (US Cellular as well)

Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. I am very sorry to hear that your Sprint end user received the SMS messages in segments.
Please note that this is a limitation on Sprint's platform where Sprint does not support concatenated messages over long codes only. Messages sent to Sprint over short codes will support concatenation. Unfortunately, this is out of Twilio's control. Twilio fully supports concatenation for both long codes and short codes, however, if the destination carriers do not support concatenation, messages will not be concatenated.

!Concat2Segment

Dear _____, 


Thank you for contacting Twilio Support.


I further investigated into messages and it appears that ____ is a unicode character (______ i.e. RIGHT SINGLE QUOTATION MARK (U+2019). Messages with one or more non-GSM characters/unicode characters, messages are charged at every 67 characters, hence your message was charged 3 segments. _______ 144/67 = 2.14 (we round to the nearest number = 3) 


You can also verify this using our SMS tool below:


http://unicode.chadrs.me/static/html5/gsm.html  


http://chadselph.github.io/smssplit/


For additional information:


https://support.twilio.com/hc/en-us/articles/223133407-How-much-does-it-cost-to-send-a-message-with-more-than-160-characters-

 

Please let me know if you have further questions.


Thanks,
**Concat - General Info on Calculating Price Breakdown of Segments (Detailed - Version 2)

9DB7CBA8-FDDE-4EE8-AAE3-76D812B36351
!ConcatSegment

Dear ______ , 


Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. I am very sorry to hear that your messages are being charged as _____ segments.


Please note that SMS messages are charged according to message segments which means that we do not charge based on numbers of messages sent. Messages are charged every 153 characters if you are using GSM characters. Messages with one or more non-GSM characters/unicode characters, messages are charged at every 67 characters. For more information about the SMS price breakdown, please see below:


https://support.twilio.com/hc/en-us/articles/223133407-How-much-does-it-cost-to-send-a-message-with-more-than-160-characters- 


To verify whether your messages have non-GSM characters, please use the tool below:


http://unicode.chadrs.me/static/html5/gsm.html


http://chadselph.github.io/smssplit/ 


If you noticed any discrepancies in pricing after taking a look at how SMS messages are charged, please provide 3 or more Message SID- https://www.twilio.com/help/faq/sms/what-is-an-sms-message-sid examples and I am more than happy to investigate further. 


Warmest Regards,
**Concat - General Info on Calculating Price Breakdown of Segments (Version 1)

Dear ______ ,
Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. I am very sorry to hear that your messages are being charged as _____ segments.
Please note that SMS messages are charged according to message segments which means that we do not charge based on numbers of messages sent. Messages are charged every 153 characters if you are using GSM characters. Messages with one or more non-GSM characters/unicode characters, messages are charged at every 67 characters. For more information about the SMS price breakdown, please see below:
https://support.twilio.com/hc/en-us/articles/223133407-How-much-does-it-cost-to-send-a-message-with-more-than-160-characters-
To verify whether your messages have non-GSM characters, please use the tool below:
http://unicode.chadrs.me/static/html5/gsm.html
http://chadselph.github.io/smssplit/
If you noticed any discrepancies in pricing after taking a look at how SMS messages are charged, please provide 3 or more Message SID- https://www.twilio.com/help/faq/sms/what-is-an-sms-message-sid examples and I am more than happy to investigate further.
Warmest Regards,
!ConcatGSMUnicode

Dear _____, 


Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. Great question!


May I ask are you referring to sending concatenated GSM messages (using the /Messages Resource)? If you are referring to sending concatenated GSM messages, messages will be segmented as 153 characters instead of at 160. The reason for this is because when you send multi segment messages, Twilio uses UDH (User Data Headers) to tell the destination carrier how to reassemble the messages on the destination handset. This takes up 6 bytes per message leaving only 153 for GSM encoded messages and 67 characters for UCS2 encoded messages. 


For more information, please take a look at the useful blog below that explains how SMS messages are segmented. 


https://www.twilio.com/blog/2017/03/what-the-heck-is-a-segment.html 


Please let me know if there is anything else I can help you with or further clarify. More than happy to help. 


Warmest Regards,


Josephine T.

Technical Support Engineer

Twilio, Inc
Concat - Why GSM and Unicode are Charged at 153 / 67 Characters

Dear _____,
Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. Great question!
May I ask are you referring to sending concatenated GSM messages (using the /Messages Resource)? If you are referring to sending concatenated GSM messages, messages will be segmented as 153 characters instead of at 160. The reason for this is because when you send multi segment messages, Twilio uses UDH (User Data Headers) to tell the destination carrier how to reassemble the messages on the destination handset. This takes up 6 bytes per message leaving only 153 for GSM encoded messages and 67 characters for UCS2 encoded messages.
For more information, please take a look at the useful blog below that explains how SMS messages are segmented.
https://www.twilio.com/blog/2017/03/what-the-heck-is-a-segment.html
Please let me know if there is anything else I can help you with or further clarify. More than happy to help.
Warmest Regards,
Josephine T. Technical Support Engineer Twilio, Inc
!Concat1600

Dear _____, 


Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. Great question!


The 1600 character limitation is not an arbitrary number. It is a character limitation used industry wide. Due to carrier bandwidth limitations,  you can send messages containing up to 1600 characters. Carriers do not support messages with more than 1600 characters at this time. 



Although on the destination handset, you will see a message of 1600 characters, however, on the backend, carriers break the 1600 characters into ten 160 character chunks. Carriers do this to conserve bandwidth and to also ensure data is not lost. Anything over 10 chunks will have a higher risk of data lost and higher difficulty of reassembling the message in the proper order. 


More information about concatenated SMS messages can be found here:


http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concatenated_SMS


Please let me know if there is anything else I can help you with or further clarify. More than happy to help. 


Warmest Regards,
Concat - Why 1600 Character Limitation

Dear _____,
Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. Great question!
The 1600 character limitation is not an arbitrary number. It is a character limitation used industry wide. Due to carrier bandwidth limitations, you can send messages containing up to 1600 characters. Carriers do not support messages with more than 1600 characters at this time.
Although on the destination handset, you will see a message of 1600 characters, however, on the backend, carriers break the 1600 characters into ten 160 character chunks. Carriers do this to conserve bandwidth and to also ensure data is not lost. Anything over 10 chunks will have a higher risk of data lost and higher difficulty of reassembling the message in the proper order.
More information about concatenated SMS messages can be found here:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concatenated_SMS
Please let me know if there is anything else I can help you with or further clarify. More than happy to help.
Warmest Regards,
!ConcatOldResource

Dear ____,


Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. I am very sorry to hear that messages are not being delivered to some of your end users.


I further investigated into this issue and it also appears that you are using the deprecated SMS/Messages Resource. With this old resource, all messages will have the delivery status of "sent". I highly recommend switching to our new /Message resource to utilize our new services. It provides services such as granular message delivery information (showing detailed delivery steps of when messages are being queued, sent,failed, delivered, undelivered) as well as concatenation and MMS support.


Please note that with the new /Messages resource you will receive detailed error notification which will provide information regarding why messages are not delivered and having this information will be extremely useful for our Support Team to help troubleshoot delivery issues.


Please consider updating to the new /Messages resource and kindly retest in sending messages to these end users. Please let me know if you have further questions regarding the error notifications you receive after you update to the new /Messages resource:


https://www.twilio.com/docs/api/rest/sending-messages  


Please update to the new resource and let me know what error notification is received on your end. Please let me know if there is anything else I can help you with or further clarify. More than happy to help. 


Warmest Regards,


Josephine T.

Technical Support Engineer

Twilio, Inc
Concat - On Old SMS/Messages Encourage Updating to /Messages Resource

Dear ____,
Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. I am very sorry to hear that messages are not being delivered to some of your end users.
I further investigated into this issue and it also appears that you are using the deprecated SMS/Messages Resource. With this old resource, all messages will have the delivery status of "sent". I highly recommend switching to our new /Message resource to utilize our new services. It provides services such as granular message delivery information (showing detailed delivery steps of when messages are being queued, sent,failed, delivered, undelivered) as well as concatenation and MMS support.
Please note that with the new /Messages resource you will receive detailed error notification which will provide information regarding why messages are not delivered and having this information will be extremely useful for our Support Team to help troubleshoot delivery issues.
Please consider updating to the new /Messages resource and kindly retest in sending messages to these end users. Please let me know if you have further questions regarding the error notifications you receive after you update to the new /Messages resource:
https://www.twilio.com/docs/api/rest/sending-messages
Please update to the new resource and let me know what error notification is received on your end. Please let me know if there is anything else I can help you with or further clarify. More than happy to help.
Warmest Regards,
Josephine T. Technical Support Engineer Twilio, Inc
